title: Research
text:
My research interests include political communication, women, gender, and politics, quantitative methods, and computational social science.
Some of my recent research papers include:

Torrential Twitter? Measuring the Severity of Harassment When Canadian Female Politicians Tweets About Climate Change
Women on the Ballot? Investigating Gendered Perceptions of the Emotional Viability of Women to Serve in Politics
Do More Subdivisions in Wards Increase Voter Turnout? An Analysis of the 2022 Toronto Municipal Election

title: INESSA DE ANGELIS
text: I am a computational political communications researcher and incoming PhD student at the University of Toronto’s Faculty of Information. My research examines the online harassment of Canadian female politicians, specifically when Tweeting about climate change and environmental policy. I am passionate about getting more women involved in politics through my work and research.

title: INESSA DE ANGELIS
text:
Inessa is a MI Candidate, incoming PhD student, and computational political communications researcher at the University of Toronto’s Faculty of Information. She has 10 years’ experience working in federal and municipal Canadian politics. She graduated Magna Cum Laude from the University of Ottawa where she holds an Honours Bachelor of Arts with a Double Major in Communication and Media Studies and History.
Inessa is passionate about the historical and contemporary experiences of women in the public sphere and aims to increase the participation of women in politics through her work and research. Her current Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada (SSHRC CGS-M) and Ontario Graduate Scholar (OGS) funded research studies the intersections of the harassment of Canadian female politicians and climate change discourse on Twitter.
Inessa enjoys publicly speaking about her experiences in Canadian politics, parliamentary affairs, and increasing the number of women elected to all levels of government. Please reach out to her if you would like her to present on her experiences, research, or to collaborate.
